   "source": [
    "# Comprehensive Fitting with PupilFit\n",
    "\n",
    "This notebook demonstrates using the PupilFit class for phase-based analysis:\n",
    "- Setting up PupilFit\n",
    "- Baseline fitting\n",
    "- Constriction phase analysis\n",
    "- Redilation fitting\n",
    "- Extracting fit parameters"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "a61d3286",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## How to use this notebook\n",
    "\n",
    "Run the notebook top-to-bottom to follow a full fitting workflow: fit a baseline model, fit the sustained constriction phase, fit redilation, and extract parameters. Each section contains a short explanation and example plots. Replace the simulated `PupilMeasurement` with your real data to apply these steps to actual recordings."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "id": "0acd1fea",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# Import necessary libraries\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "import pypipr"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "501f0676",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "\"\"\"\n",
    "Pupillary Light Response Model\n",
    "\n",
    "Models pupil diameter changes in response to light stimuli using linear and\n",
    "exponential functions, based on Feigl et al. (2011).\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "Phases:\n",
    "-------\n",
    "\n",
    "1. BASELINE (y = y0)\n",
    "    - Description: Flat linear model fit to 10s prestimulus period.\n",
    "    - Defined from:\n",
    "        - Start Time: -infinity\n",
    "        - End Time: light stimuli onset \n",
    "    - Variables:\n",
    "        - y0: Baseline pupil diameter (mean before stimulus)\n",
    "2. PLR LATENCY PERIOD (y = undefined)\n",
    "    - Description: Undefined period after light onset and before constriction.\n",
    "    - Defined from:\n",
    "        - Start Time: light onset\n",
    "        - End Time: light onset + PLR latency\n",
    "3. CONSTRICT (y = cv * (x + t_constrict) + y0)\n",
    "    - Description: Linear model from light onset to max constriction.\n",
    "    - Defined from:\n",
    "        - Start: light onset + PLR latency\n",
    "        - End: time of maximum constriction\n",
    "    - Variables:\n",
    "        - x: Time since light onset\n",
    "        - t_constrict: Time shift to light onset + PLR latency\n",
    "        - cv: Constriction velocity\n",
    "        - y0: Baseline pupil diameter\n",
    "4. SUSTAINED (y = m * (x + t_sustained) + c)\n",
    "    - Description: Linear model from max constriction to light offset.\n",
    "    - Defined from:\n",
    "        - Start: time of maximum constriction\n",
    "        - End: light offset\n",
    "    - Variables:\n",
    "        - x: Time since max constriction\n",
    "        - t_sustained: Time shift to max constriction\n",
    "        - m: Slope of sustained constriction\n",
    "        - c: Diameter at max constriction\n",
    "5. REDILATION (y = S * exp(k * (x + t_redilation) + P)\n",
    "    - Description: Exponential model for redilation after light offset.\n",
    "    - Defined from:\n",
    "        - Start: light offset\n",
    "        - End: + infinity\n",
    "    - Variables:\n",
    "        - x: Time since light offset\n",
    "        - t_redilation: Time shift to light offset\n",
    "        - S: Scaling constant\n",
    "        - k: Redilation velocity\n",
    "        - P: Plateau pupil diameter\n",
    "\n",
    "Notes:\n",
    "------\n",
    "- All time values (x) are in seconds.\n",
    "\"\"\""
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "5137ae5f",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Baseline fitting\n",
    "\n",
    "Fit a flat baseline model to the prestimulus period. This captures additive offsets and provides a reference level for later phases. The example below fits a baseline across the pre-stimulus window and overlays the fit on the raw trace."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "id": "3420bb4b",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Parameters:\n",
      "c: 8.087935869048717\n",
      "Formula:\n",
      "y = 8.0879 from -inf to -1.0000\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "name": "stderr",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "C:\\Users\\20182727\\OneDrive - TU Eindhoven\\Documents\\Tools\\pypipr_package\\pypipr\\analysis\\fitting\\phase_fits.py:32: UserWarning: Baseline measurement is often 10 seconds long. If this is not the case, results may be inaccurate.\n",
      "  warnings.warn(\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x1f7c8b423c0>"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 2,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 800x200 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "pm = pypipr.load_simulated_pupil()\n",
    "\n",
    "time = pm.get_time()\n",
    "size = pm.get_size()\n",
    "\n",
    "# First, get some timings.\n",
    "stimuli_onset, stimuli_offset = pm.get_light_stimulus().get_time()\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "baseline_fit = pypipr.FitBaseline(time, size, -np.inf, stimuli_onset)\n",
    "baseline_fit.fit()\n",
    "print(\"Parameters:\")\n",
    "for param_name, param_value in zip(\n",
    "    baseline_fit.get_param_names(), baseline_fit.get_params()\n",
    "):\n",
    "    print(f\"{param_name}: {param_value}\")\n",
    "print(\"Formula:\")\n",
    "print(baseline_fit.get_formula_string())\n",
    "\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 2), sharex=True)\n",
    "pm.plot(ax=ax, label=\"Original Data\", color=\"gray\")\n",
    "pm.plot_light_stimulus(ax=ax)\n",
    "baseline_fit.plot(ax=ax, label=\"Fit\", color=\"red\")\n",
    "ax.legend()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "133f5a61",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Constriction / sustain fitting\n",
    "\n",
    "Fit the constriction and sustained phases. Typically the constriction phase is modeled as a linear segment up to maximum constriction, followed by a sustained segment until stimulus offset. The example below demonstrates fitting the sustain model (time of max constriction may need to be provided)."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "id": "4f5f8638",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Parameters:\n",
      "m: -0.023014941804691783\n",
      "c: 4.020110736810595\n",
      "Formula:\n",
      "y = -0.0230 * (x + -0.7000) + 4.0201 from -0.7000 to 0.0000\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x1f7ccc39590>"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 3,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",

      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "pm = pypipr.load_simulated_pupil()\n",
    "\n",
    "time = pm.get_time()\n",
    "size = pm.get_size()\n",
    "\n",
    "# First, get some timings.\n",
    "stimuli_onset, stimuli_offset = pm.get_light_stimulus().get_time()\n",
    "time_of_max_constriction = -0.7  # This currently still needs to be specified manually.\n",
    "\n",
    "sustain_fit = pypipr.FitSustain(time, size, time_of_max_constriction, stimuli_offset)\n",
    "sustain_fit.fit()\n",
    "print(\"Parameters:\")\n",
    "for param_name, param_value in zip(\n",
    "    sustain_fit.get_param_names(), sustain_fit.get_params()\n",
    "):\n",
    "    print(f\"{param_name}: {param_value}\")\n",
    "print(\"Formula:\")\n",
    "print(sustain_fit.get_formula_string())\n",
    "\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 2), sharex=True)\n",
    "pm.plot(ax=ax, label=\"Original Data\", color=\"gray\")\n",
    "pm.plot_light_stimulus(ax=ax)\n",
    "sustain_fit.plot(ax=ax, label=\"Sustain Fit\", color=\"blue\")\n",
    "ax.legend()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "6e47e810",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Redilation fitting\n",
    "\n",
    "After stimulus offset, redilation is often modeled with an exponential. This section fits the redilation phase and overlays the fit. Adjust fit windows and initial guesses as needed for your data."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "id": "2e925207",
   "metadata": {},

    "## Convenience wrapper: PupilFit\n",
    "\n",
    "`PupilFit` provides a convenience wrapper to organize individual phase fits and collect parameters. The example below shows how to assemble a `PupilFit` object, attach a manually-fitted sustain fit, and inspect all parameters."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 6,
   "id": "615bb283",
   "metadata": {},

      "\tConstriction: y = nan * (x) + nan from -1.0000 to 0.0000\n",

     ]

   "source": [
    "# There is a convienience function to do the above all together, that also allows determining pupil metrics.\n",
    "# Note. Currently the sustain fit is not yet automatically fitted, and needs to be defined manually.\n",
    "pupil_fit = pypipr.PupilFit(pm)\n",
    "\n",
    "# We need to manually define the sustain fit for now.\n",
    "sustain_fit = pypipr.FitSustain(\n",
    "    time, size, time_of_max_constriction, stimuli_offset\n",
    ")\n",
    "sustain_fit.fit()\n",
    "pupil_fit.sustain_fit = sustain_fit\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "print(\"All parameters:\")\n",
    "for fit_name, param_values in pupil_fit.get_all_params().items():\n",
    "    print(f\"{fit_name}:\")\n",
    "    for param_name, param_value in param_values.items():\n",
    "        print(f\"  {param_name}: {param_value}\")\n",
    "\n",
    "print(pupil_fit.get_formula_strings())\n",
    "\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 2), sharex=True)\n",
    "pm.plot(ax=ax, label=\"Original Data\", color=\"gray\")\n",
    "pm.plot_light_stimulus(ax=ax)\n",
    "pupil_fit.plot(ax=ax)\n",
    "ax.legend()"
   ]
  },

   "source": [
    "## Compare metrics from data vs fit\n",
    "\n",
    "After fitting, you can compute pupil metrics both from raw data and from the fit (useful to assess the fit's ability to reproduce metrics like PIPR). The example below compares 6s-PIPR from the measured trace and from the fitted model."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 7,
   "id": "eaccba7b",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "PIPR 6s (data): 6.57\n",
      "PIPR 6s (fit ): 6.62\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# This pupil_fit object can now also be used to calculate pupil metrics.\n",
    "pipr_6s = pm.pipr_6s()\n",
    "pipr_6s_fit = pupil_fit.pipr_6s()\n",
    "\n",
    "print(f\"PIPR 6s (data): {pipr_6s:.2f}\")\n",
    "print(f\"PIPR 6s (fit ): {pipr_6s_fit:.2f}\")"
   ]
  }
